Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Surface vulnerabilities in package detail page" (#8343) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
First steps in addressing https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7650
In this PR we have:
- the feature flag
- initial changes to the view model
- initial changes to the view--we'll iterate on this in consultation with PM (for example, we don't yet have the distinction between a customer view and an owner view of the vulnerability expander, we will need to discuss tooltip and other language used, etc)--but we're under a feature flag in order to do this iteratively
- test coverage will need to be augmented (refactored, actually) and I want to do this in a different PR, as some class renames will affect vulnerability ingestion code--it will be noisy, so I'll separate it out for reviewing

Here is the current state of the view, highlights in red boxes:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14225979/101106161-33711d00-361b-11eb-80e9-40e734ec3e66.png)

Because deprecations and vulnerabilities share the same bang, you'll see a combining of the logic in the view, and combination messages in the tooltip. These can be sweetened later as well, of course.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Issue with Visual Studio packaging" (#8342) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.8.2

I have a very large solution containing multiple projects. 
The project is open source, and has forked from the original, meaning the nuget package names have changed.

The issue seems to be one of the package being built with the namespaces instead of the package name.

Namespace into
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22121540/101077798-3d543b00-359d-11eb-82ad-3f574d6be186.png)

Package Info
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22121540/101077710-1d247c00-359d-11eb-8ced-632f2d435f97.png)

When these are imported into a plugin, the following error is reported. The nugets are in a locally stored folder.
```
NU1101: Unable to find package MediaBrowser.Model. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Local, nuget.org
```

On further investigation - the following is showing under dependencies.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22121540/101078053-8e642f00-359d-11eb-96ec-a717c6e727cf.png)

MediaBrowser.Common and MediaBrowser.Model don't exist with that name as packages, but are called Jellyfin.Common and Jellyfin.Model as like above both are packaged with a different name.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Dependency injection singleton for markdig pipeline build " (#8341) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "NuGet error when compiling the code generated by the WinUI3 Preview 3 template" (#10351) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Problem details

When compiling a new WinUI3 Preview 3 project, nuget returns an harmless error.
The error is printed sistematically, even when repeating the "Restore NuGet packages" from the solution explorer.
**Anyway the application works correctly**

Versions used:
- VS2019 16.9.0 P1
- .NET 5.0.100
- NuGet.exe Version: 5.8.0.6930
- OS: Windows 10 20H2 (19042.630)

## Repro

1. Install the officiasl WinUI3 Preview 3 Visual Studio extensions (this is needed for the templates)

2. Create a new project using the template (for C#) called: "Blank App, Packaged (WinUI in Desktop)"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5183152/100993336-95ffe580-3555-11eb-818b-fdb15dffbcbc.png)

3. Build the app and open the VS Output Window:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5183152/100993597-e70fd980-3555-11eb-9d86-0bac5c37657f.png)
The error message is: **NuGet package restore failed. Please see Error List window for detailed warnings and errors.**

4.  The error list does not provide any detail:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5183152/100993770-1b839580-3556-11eb-8471-f42beb045e3e.png)

## Other tests

A. `dotnet restore`  (no error messages):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5183152/100993911-44a42600-3556-11eb-8c91-2591b015ff8a.png)

B. `nuget.exe restore -v d`  (no error messages)
```
h:\xyz>nuget.exe restore -v d
NuGet Version: 5.8.0.6930
Restoring NuGet packages for solution h:\xyz\WinUIExperimentsSolution.sln.
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '16.9.0.52904' from 'c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Preview\MSBuild\Current\Bin'. Use option -MSBuildVersion to force nuget to use a specific version of MSBuild.
MSBuild P2P timeout [ms]: 120000
c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Preview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\msbuild.exe "C:\Users\raffaeler\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\yrlfpwgc.pbh.nugetinputs.targets" /t:GenerateRestoreGraphFile /nologo /nr:false /v:q /p:NuGetRestoreTargets="C:\Users\raffaeler\AppData\Local\Temp\NuGetScratch\go1xkdkx.4rj.nugetrestore.targets" /p:RestoreUseCustomAfterTargets="True" /p:RestoreTaskAssemblyFile="H:\util\nuget.exe" /p:RestoreSolutionDirectory="h:\xyz\\" /p:SolutionDir="h:\xyz\\" /p:SolutionName="WinUIExperimentsSolution"

Running restore with 8 concurrent jobs.
Reading project file h:\xyz\FirstApp\FirstApp\FirstApp.csproj.
The restore inputs for 'FirstApp' have changed. Continuing restore.
Restoring packages for h:\xyz\FirstApp\FirstApp\FirstApp.csproj...
Restoring packages for .NETCoreApp,Version=v5.0...
Resolving conflicts for net5.0-windows10.0.18362...
Scanning packages for runtime.json files...
Restoring packages for net5.0-windows10.0.18362/win10-arm64...
Resolving conflicts for net5.0-windows10.0.18362/win10-arm64...

Resolving conflicts for net5.0-windows10.0.18362/win10-x86...
Checking compatibility of packages on net5.0-windows10.0.18362.
Checking compatibility for FirstApp 1.0.0 with net5.0-windows10.0.18362.
Checking compatibility for Microsoft.VCRTForwarders.140 1.0.7 with net5.0-windows10.0.18362.
```

Events.RelatedBody:
There's a lot of tooling that could benefit from this. 

cc @zivkan

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Feature Request: Automatically Open readme.md Files" (#10353) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm not exactly sure where to put this, and the prompt text doesn't seem to be appropriate for this.

In Nuget.Client:

I would like `readme.md` files to automatically open the same way that `readme.txt` files do.

Looking at the code, this appears it would need:
* a new constant in `src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.PackageManagement/Utility/Constants.cs`
* modifying `OpenReadmeFile()` in `src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.PackageManagement/NuGetPackageManager.cs`
  * I think I would factor out computing the directory
  * As it is now, the relevant changes would need to happen on lines 3326 and 3335, I think
  * In both places, immediately check `File.Exists(readmeFilePath)` and if `false` set `readmeFilePath` to point at the `.md` instead
    * Not that great of a solution, I think I'd prefer the refactor
* Define the behavior for the case when they both exist to prefer opening `readme.txt`

I might rather have `ReadmeFileName` be a list of names (and renamed to `ReadmeFileNames`) and cycle through the list, but that requires more work for dubious gains.

I am not interested in signing a contributor license agreement at this time, otherwise I would consider just doing this myself.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VS Solution manager throws null exception for during debugging" (#10352) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I recently noticed there is null exception kept throwing when try to open PMUI/PMC. 
It looks due to recent synchronous code with async ones causing this timing issue. It doesn't guarantee `init` is done before code start is using supposedly already initialized things.
I don't think my implementation  is expensive, it's supposed to happen only once one way another, I'm just making sure it finish before we use it.
Also jebriede [reported it](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:00d019d741b44e54baadd67ef7aeb41d@thread.skype/1606247461775?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47&groupId=ad34ac55-6785-4e7c-82c3-7ba405d30c3c&parentMessageId=1606247461775&teamName=NuGet&channelName=Client&createdTime=1606247461775).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8766776/100144755-1898ee80-2e4c-11eb-9fba-c4e64fe331ab.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
